title: How to Make Homemade Chocolate Lebkuchen

steps.headline: Grease and flour a jellyroll pan.
Combine and boil the sugar, honey, and water substance in a saucepan.
Remove the mixture from the heat.
Add the chocolate chips, almonds, candied fruit, eggs and orange juice into another bowl.
Sift and stir in, the second bowl's mixture with flour, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, baking soda and baking powder.
Cover the bowl and refrigerate for 2-3 days.
Pour the first bowl's mixture into the pan, followed by pouring the second bowl's mixture into the same saucepan only in this order.
Form these cookies into their own separate entry.
steps.description: Chocolate Lebkuchen cookies are rather round cookies. Spoon them out. These cookies will tend to puff up after baking. They have a rather solid base that does taste a bit like the unconsecrated wafer you'd taste when going up for Holy Communion (no, they aren't blessed) at a church, that holds the cookie together. (If you take a look at a store-bought one, the wafers that hold it together, traditionally are white, though the coloring doesn't matter). Leave at least an inch of space between the cookies because they'll spread out when they cook. You can usually fit 6-8 (dependent on their size that you've crafted them to be) cookies on a full-sized cookie sheet at a time.

steps.headline: Refrigerate for a few days.
steps.description: They must be significantly chilled and hard, for them to be remotely close to the real product.

text: Grease and flour a jellyroll pan.  Combine and boil the sugar, honey, and water substance in a saucepan.  Remove the mixture from the heat. Let it cool. Add the chocolate chips, almonds, candied fruit, eggs and orange juice into another bowl.  Sift and stir in, the second bowl's mixture with flour, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, baking soda and baking powder.  Cover the bowl and refrigerate for 2-3 days.  Preheat your oven to 325 °F (163 °C).  Pour the first bowl's mixture into the pan, followed by pouring the second bowl's mixture into the same saucepan only in this order.  Form these cookies into their own separate entry. Chocolate Lebkuchen cookies are rather round cookies. Spoon them out. These cookies will tend to puff up after baking. They have a rather solid base that does taste a bit like the unconsecrated wafer you'd taste when going up for Holy Communion (no, they aren't blessed) at a church, that holds the cookie together. (If you take a look at a store-bought one, the wafers that hold it together, traditionally are white, though the coloring doesn't matter). Leave at least an inch of space between the cookies because they'll spread out when they cook. You can usually fit 6-8 (dependent on their size that you've crafted them to be) cookies on a full-sized cookie sheet at a time. Bake these cookies for 35-40 minutes.  Let the cookies cool.  Refrigerate for a few days. They must be significantly chilled and hard, for them to be remotely close to the real product.
